resources.string: Choose an effect to get started or the tutorial button in the upper right-hand corner to learn how to operate the application and get more technical information.

Reverb or Echo functions are used to simulate the effect of reverberation in a large hall or cavern. Several delayed signals are added to the original recorded signal to add the echo effect. For this application\'s purposes, the original sounds data is repeated in short bursts and added to the original signal. These repeats have diminishing effects so the echo effects don\'t last forever and do eventually die off.

The low pass filter on this application only passes data from the signal under a certain range. The range is determined by the signal so this is not a set value. When you play back the signal, only lower amplitude sounds will be played back because the filter will capture the higher amplitude data points.

The high pass filter on this application only passes data from the signal over a certain range. The range is determined by the signal so this is not a set value. When you play back the signal, only higher amplitude sounds will be played back because the filter will capture the lower amplitude data points.

The reverse function in this application takes the last sample and makes it to the first and takes the first sample and makes it the last. It does this for all the data points in the middle as well. So the sound you hear will sound backwards to what it originally was. The audio waveform should also look backwards from what it originally looked like when you recorded your signal.

Also referred to as Decimation, this is the process of reducing the sampling rate of a signal. Decimation reduces the data rate of the size of the data, in this application\'s case we reduce the size by half. This can also cause degradation of the signal because you are cutting out important pieces of data from the signal.

Also referred to as Interpolation, this is the process of creating new data points within the range of the known data points. This can be done by converting a sampled digital signal (such as a recording of your voice) to a higher sampling rate. In this application\'s case, the sample rate is multiplied by two.

1. Press Rec and start speaking in a normal voice.
2. Press stop when finished.
3. Select function button you want to apply.
4. Press Play button to listen to your signal.
